text: So is everyone ready??
We shall  start in a minute or two.  We will wait for the rest for a few minutes.
So before we start I want you guys to do  a quick thing,  we need a second text file for this session. So go into the terminal and open up the unix-smp directory
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FAUBW9WRM/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview:
Now once you have done this type down the following command
echo 'The quick brown; fox jumps over the lazy  dog' > sample.txt
file.preview_highlight:
Now once you have done this type down the following command
echo 'The quick brown; fox jumps over the lazy  dog' > sample.txt

text: the space between lazy and dog must be a tab
tell me once you have done this
this basically puts it in sample.txt right?
Yes thats what it does.
Its copies down the text into the file that we have specified
tab is not working
i used two spaces instead
Or you can go into the text file and press tab between both
oh ok
Okay so now last session we covered a few text manipulation commands now we shall continue with them.
First command we'll be learning about is the cut command. It extracts portions of text from a file.
Now execute this command
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FAU7ET5C6/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: cut -c 5 sample.txt

text: What do you get?
the fifth character?
correct
only q
So as you found out ,this outputs the 5th character in each line of the file. In this case it is "q", note that the space also counts as a character.
Now execute this
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FASQ2MGE5/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: cut -f 2 sample.txt

text: What do you get?
And why?
the sentence
complete sentence as it is
Are you sure you put a tab space before dog
i am only getting dog
but i dont know why
Yes if you are getting Dog its the right answer
yeah i got dog
the others put a tab space before dog and re execute it
i guess it considers tab to be the start of the 2nd line so it prints whatever is in the second line
You are kinda right
Got dog too
So the reason why we got the above output is because we extract the contents by a field
The -f or field flag cuts text based off of fields, by default it uses TABs as delimiters, so everything separated by a TAB is considered a field. You should see "dog" as your output.
We use 2 here to print the second feild
Got it?
what's a field?
Now try this one out and tell the output
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FASQ72AAV/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: cut -f 1 -d ";" sample.txt

text: <@UAH30B5KQ> commented on <@UAMHTGNG0>’s file <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FASQ72AAV/-.sh|Untitled>: The quick brown

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: cut -f 1 -d ";" sample.txt

text: Yes exactly and do youknow why?
-d tells that ; is a delimiter
yes
; is now the delimiter
1 for the first field, -d means everything before the delimiter
Now what we did here is that we  changed the TAB delimiter to a ";" delimiter and since we are cutting the first field, the result should be "The quick brown".
Yes all of you are right
Now consider the first command I asked to execute
instead of 5 what will happen if we use -5
everything before the nth character
The q
prints till the 5th character
So as Nakul and Abhinav pointed out all  the charcter before the 5th charcter will be printed i.e when we use minus all the characters before the nth character will be printed.
So that about it for cut. Any doubts? If not we will move on to the  next command
Ok now we will go into tr or the translate command.
The tr (translate) command allows you to translate a set of characters into another set of characters.
Now try this out
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FATAZRQ3C/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
tr a-z A-Z
hello

text: What is the output?
HELLO
HELLO
Yes, thats correct.  Great job
so this works like define in C?

Actually no. There a particular string that you define is replaced  by a number or function that you give it. Here tr is used to translate the world into another. In  the above example we translated all lower case characters to uppercase <http://characters.As|characters.As> you can see we made the ranges of a-z into A-Z and all text we type that is lowercase gets uppercased.
Everybody clear with that?
Okay now the next command that we will look into is the paste command.
So do you guys still have the older version of the sample.txt .The one we used last session.
If not delete this one  and download the other one into the unix-smp directory
Tell me  when you are ready
the grocery list one right?
Ok now the paste command is similar to the cat command, it merges lines together in a file.
so execute the following two commands and tell me the difference
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FASQPSG6M/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: paste -s sample2.txt

text: <@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FASQQ458R/-.lua|Untitled>

file.name: -.lua
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: paste -d ' ' -s sample2.txt

text: Guys got it?
Fred appBetty limes 14lons 2
for the first command
Betty limes 14lons 2
for 2nd command
So what is the difference that you find?
So I will explain  the two commands

Now in the first command, default delimiter for paste is TAB, so now there is one line with TABs separating each word. In the second command we changed this delimiter (-d) to space. Now everything should be on one line delimited by spaces.
Any doubts?
Guys are you paying attention because I don't see any response from you or is something thats covered hard to understand?
is the last line separated with tabs?
My net is shitty so i cant respond on time xD
For which command?
I'm a little confused so I'm just letting it settle in
the first command
Oh cool XD <@UAFPA8G59>, if you have doubts do ask <@UAH8CT90X>
We are in no hurry
why doesnt it print the first line fully?
then it directly jumps to the last line?
So paste works the same way as cat does, the only difference being the delimiter stuff, is it?
Like here all the lines must be separated by a tab. I'm not quite sure why your first line is not printed ,because it is coming for me.
Yes exactly.
ok
Okay so now we will go into the next command that is the sort command
so is paste a more powerful version of cat?
Now as the name suggests the sort command sorts lines in the alphabetical order.
Execute the following command
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FATBPU602/-.java|Untitled>

file.name: -.java
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: sort sample.txt

text: You do get the lines in a sorted fashion don't you?
By powerful what do you mean?
See basically cat print down the file  as it is , but what paste does is it past all the lines one after the other into a single line. Also there is a provision to change the delimiter in paste.
okay then try out this
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FATBTPVL2/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: sort -r file1.txt

text: <@UAGR7CFEJ> commented on <@UAMHTGNG0>’s file <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FATBTPVL2/-.sh|Untitled>: in reverse order

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: sort -r file1.txt

text: i mean with more options for pasting?
Exactly using the -r reverses the sort command
Yes in a way you can say that
Thats about it for the sort command. Any doubts?
Okay now the next command that we will be looking into will be the sed command

The Linux operating system makes use of terminal commands to work with a computer's file system. The primary use of the Linux command sed, which is short for stream editor, is to modify each line of a file or stream by replacing specified parts of the line.
For example try out this one
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FAT91B3M1/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: sed 's/12/30/' sample.txt > sample2.txt

text: What does it do?
replaces 12 with 30
the contents of sample2 got replaced with those of sample
Actually the contents in sample2 is the same except that all the 12 are replaced by 30
So what we did here was that all the 12 in sampl is replaced by 30 into a new file called sample2
got it?
oh all right got it
So what we did here was making text substitutions with sed. This is one of its main functons.
so somewhat like command-line text editing?
It is also used in another function which we will see in the following example.
Yes that is is what text manipulation  is all about basically.
<@UAMHTGNG0> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAMHTGNG0/FAT5EHACU/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight: sed -n '/Mark/p' sample.txt > sample2.txt

text: Tell what do you get here?
prints only the lines with mark
Yes exactly. Good job.
So what we did in this command was that we used it to filter the lines into the other text file
that is the second use of sed command i.e to  filter the content.
Is that clear?
So thats it for this session and with that we  come to an end with text manipulation . Thank you guys. Hope you felt the session to be informative and helpful
